metadata.title: Distinguishing between COVID-19 and the common cold in a primary care setting 1 -comparison of patients with positive and negative SARS-CoV-2 PCR results. 2 3

body_text.text: Background: Combating the COVID-19 pandemic is a major challenge for health 38 systems, citizens and policy makers worldwide. Early detection of affected patients 39 within the huge population of patients with common cold symptoms is an important 40 element of this effort but often hindered by limited testing resources. We aimed to 41 identify predictive risk profiles for a positive PCR result in primary care. The COVID-19 pandemic is a major challenge for health systems, citizens and policy 69 makers worldwide (1). The early political implementation of individual distancing has 70 slowed down the reproduction rate of the virus in Germany significantly (2) is the question of how far positive and negative patients differ in their initial clinical 83 presentation. The more precisely physicians use SARS-CoV-2 PCR testing, the more 84 efficient it is. Statistically, this is reflected in Baye's theorem: The quality of a test is not 85 only determined by specificity and sensitivity, but also depends on the pre-test 86 probability of the event to be tested. Thus, if the pre-test probability for COVID-19 is 87 higher, the probability that a SARS-CoV-2 PCR-positive patient is actually ill (positive-88 predictive value = PPV) is increased (4) . In this multi-center, cross-sectional study, the characteristics of patients who tested 98 positive and negative for COVID-19 were assessed. A total of 26 office-based 99 specialists for internal and/or general medicine with a full primary care mandate from 14 100 different locations participated in the study. 101 All locations collected patient-related data based on a uniform quality standard in the 102 documentation of COVID-19 suspect cases that we provided. 103 Each site reported anonymous data on all SARS-CoV-2 PCR swabs taken. These In order to ensure that there was no excessive distortion in the patient collective due to 125 the convenience sampling of practices, age and sex of the tested persons were 126 compared with demographic data from a large national sample. 127 128 . The odds ratio (OR) for a positive COVID-19 PCR was increased in 184 patients who had contact with an infected person who were older and in patients with 185 anosmia and decreased in patients suffering from a sore throat. . body_text.text: The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted May 5, 2020. Factors that were associated with a negative test result 226 Negative tests were associated with the symptom "sore throat". This result is consistent 227 with the low prevalence of the symptom "sore throat" in confirmed COVID-19 cases (6). 228 The correlation found between age and test results is marginal (younger people were 229 tested negative more often) and may be explained by local outbreaks in nursing homes. 230 This effect will most likely dissolve due to diffusion processes during the course of the 231 pandemic and may not be present in countries with a more homogenous spreading 232 pattern.
body_text.section: (which was not certified by peer review)

body_text.text: Factors that were associated with a positive test result 235 Positive tests were associated with confirmed contact. This was to be expected, but it 236 was surprising that this also applied to asymptomatic patients. He et al. concluded that 237 45% of infections occur in the pre-symptomatic phase of the patient, i.e. the patient is 238 still asymptomatic but already has large amounts of virus replicated in the throat and is 239 highly contagious (9). This result underlines the particular relevance of contact 240 anamnesis for the test decision, but also the relevance of early isolation of potentially 241 affected contacts. 242 Of particular clinical importance is the observed association between the symptom 243 anosmia and a positive PCR result. Anosmia has already been described as a relevant 244 COVID-19 symptom in other studies, but this is the first study to show that anosmia may 245 be a useful discriminator between COVID-19 and other, endemic respiratory tract 246 infections (8,10,11). Since the examined patients mainly presented with fever, cough, 247 muscle pain and other cold symptoms, which are common with endemic respiratory 248 . FIGREF0.text: Multi-center cross-sectional cohort study on predictive characteristics over a 43 period of 4 weeks in primary care patients in Germany. We evaluated age, sex, reason 44 for testing, risk factors, symptoms, and expected PCR result for their impact on the total, 374 patients in 14 primary care centers received SARS-CoV-2 PCR 47 swab testing and were included in this analysis. A fraction of 10.7% (n=40) tested 48 positive for COVID-19. Patients who reported anosmia had a higher odds ratio (OR: 49 4.54; 95%-CI: 1.51-13.67) for a positive test result while patients with a sore throat had 50 a lower OR (OR: 0.33; 95%-CI: 0.11-0.97). Patients who had a first grade contact with 51 an infected persons and showed symptoms themselves also had an increased OR for 52 positive testing (OR: 5.16; 95% CI: 1.72-15.51). This correlation was also present when 53 they themselves were still asymptomatic (OR: 12.55; 95% CI: 3.97-39.67). 54 Conclusion: The reported contact to an infected person is the most important factor for 55 a positive PCR result, independent of any symptoms of illness in the tested patient. 56 Those persons with contact to an infected person should always get a PCR test. If no 57 contact is reported and testing material is scarce, anosmia should increase the 58 likelihood of performing a test, while a sore throat should decrease it.

FIGREF2.text: , sex, reason for the test, risk factors, symptoms leading to the test, result 105 expected by the GP and actual PCR result. All data were noted on a structured 106 documentation sheet and passed on anonymously for evaluation. The documentation 107 form was prepared on the basis of the recommendations of the RKI as well as the 108 available evidence on symptoms and risk factors for COVID-19 and was subjected to 109 pre-testing with experienced family doctors (5,6,7,8). The test reason "Patient is contact 110 person without symptoms" was included in addition to the test reasons recommended 111 by the RKI, as it had already been used frequently in everyday practice. 112 113 The survey period was from 24.03.2020 to 17.04.2020 -this period was chosen 114 because the RKI criteria for carrying out a PCR remained stable. 115 116 Tests that had been carried out for procedural reasons and did not correspond to a 117 specific clinical indication were excluded (e.g. testing of recovered patients after end of 118 quarantine). There were no other exclusion criteria. 119 120The participating GP's practices represented a "convenience sample". Selection criteria 121 were the performance of smear tests, structured documentation and willingness

FIGREF3.text: 132 influencing factors (symptoms, test reason, etc.) on the test result (PCR positive 133 yes/no). Statistically significant influencing factors were then transferred to a logistic 134 regression model to check their effect strength. Missing data were reported in the 135 descriptive part, for the regression model missing values were assigned to the more 136 frequent result (deviation to the middle), a proportion of missing values >5% practices tested n=374 patients per swab test for SARS-CoV-2 in the 148 investigated period. Of these, 10.7% (n=40) tested positive. The symptom anosmia, as 149 well as contact with infected persons, was associated with a positive PCR result. 150 151 A total of 26 specialists with a general practitioner mandate at 14 different locations 152 (individual and group practices) from North Rhine-Westphalia, Rhineland-Palatinate, 153 Hesse and Saxony-Anhalt (four of 16 federal German states) took part in the study. All 154 practices are located in urban and rural districts with moderate to increased COVID-19 155 activity (cumulative incidence 50-250 cases per 100,000 inhabitants) (2).

FIGREF4.text: patients were 58.5% female and the median age was 44 years. Further 165 characteristics of the investigated cohort can be found intable 1

FIGREF7.text: result of this work is the shown correlation between a positive COVID-19 PCR 200 and the symptom anosmia as well as a confirmed contact with an infected person, 201 regardless of whether the tested person itself had symptoms or not. work, predictive factors for a positive COVID-19 PCR were investigated for the 205 first time. The evaluation was performed with a multicentric approach and was based on 206 a common documentation standard. The selection of the practices was non-207 randomized, as a rapid implementation of the study was preferred to a lengthier 208 randomized selection in respect to the pandemics' rapid evolution. This may have 209 resulted in a distortion of the investigated patient collective, although, no conspicuous 210 deviations were found in comparison to the demographic data of all patients tested in 211 Germany as published by the RKI: the age median in our population was 44 years (IQR: 212 31-59) compared to 42 years (IQR: 29-56) in a sample of +1.000.tests decreased towards the end of the investigation period, which parallels 221 the decreasing number of new COVID-19 infections in Germany as well as the end

FIGREF8.text: acute or chronic rhinitis in COVID-19 is striking (8,10-12). Reporting 251 from our clinical experience with COVID-19, anosmia was sometimes so pronounced in 252 COVID-19 patients that it was presented as the sole symptom upon presentation.253    Therefore, we recommend that patients are always asked for fever, cough, dyspnea and254 anosmia as part of the initial stratification process. In case of isolated anosmia in the 255 absence of chronic or acute rhinosinusitis, we recommend a testing for COVID-19 256 infection, as already suggested in a French case series by Villalba et al. of first degree contacts, consistent tracing of infection chains and 261 quarantine will remain essential parts of the COVID-19 containment strategy. Our data 262 show that the testing of all first-degree contacts, including asymptomatic ones can be of 263 merit and that anosmia, even as an isolated symptom is a clear indication of COVIDare an essential part of the testing strategy in most countries. 266 Based on their intensive experience with respiratory tract infections, they are able to 267 clinically assess a large number of patients with cold symptoms in a short period of time 268 and, if necessary, perform PCR testing. In addition, compared to other countries, Germany has implemented an intensive testing strategy 72 for new infections using PCR swab testing, funded by the national social health73    insurance system (statutory health insurance). According to date from "Robert-KochInstitut" (RKI), roughly an equivalent to the CDC in the US, 176 participating laboratories 75 reported a number of 348,619 PCR tests carried out in calendar week 12/2020 (419 76 tests/100.000 inhabitants).
